hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by the uncle of Abd al-Jalil al-Filastini: I heard the Messenger of Allah ﷺ saying: 'Whoever suppresses his anger while he has the power to implement it, Allah the Most High will fill his breast with security and faith.' The narrator (the collector of the hadith) thinks he said 'his breast'.

narrators.name: Duhayim
narrators.full_name: Sallam ibn Amr al-Yaskuri or al-Basri

narrators.name: Ibn Abi Fuday k
narrators.full_name: Umar ibn Ishaq ibn Ubayd Allah ibn Abi Fuday k
narrators.alternative_names: Umar ibn Ishaq, Abu Hafs al-Qurashi

narrators.name: Daud ibn Qais
narrators.full_name: Daud ibn Qais al-Awdi

narrators.name: Abd al-Jalil al-Filastini
narrators.full_name: Abd al-Jalil al-Filastini

narrators.name: The uncle of Abd al-Jalil
narrators.full_name: Unknown companion (referred to as the uncle of Abd al-Jalil al-Filastini)

narrators.name: Prophet Muhammad ﷺ
narrators.full_name: Muhammad ibn Abdullah ibn Abd al-Muttalib ibn Hashim

chainIssues: Abd al-Jalil al-Filastini is majhul al-hal (unknown condition) - major reliability concern
The 'uncle' is an unnamed companion, creating an implicit disconnection (mursal)
Multiple عَنْ terms used in the chain (Abd al-Jalil and uncle), introducing ambiguity
Ibn Abi Fuday k is classified as a mudallis (category 3) but uses direct transmission term نا, which is acceptable

potential_issues.issue: Abd al-Jalil al-Filastini is majhul al-hal (his reliability condition is unknown)
potential_issues.impact: This significantly weakens the chain as we have no reliable information about this narrator's accuracy or integrity

potential_issues.issue: The uncle of Abd al-Jalil is unnamed - his identity is unclear
potential_issues.impact: This creates an implicit disconnection (mursal) in the chain as the companion is not explicitly identified

potential_issues.issue: Multiple عَنْ transmissions used (Abd al-Jalil → uncle), introducing ambiguity about direct hearing
potential_issues.impact: While Abd al-Jalil and uncle use عَنْ, this could indicate indirect transmission, though with the companion being relatively trustworthy as a companion, the impact is somewhat mitigated

potential_issues.issue: Ibn Abi Fuday k, though using direct transmission (نا), is classified as a mudallis (category 3)
potential_issues.impact: However, since he uses direct transmission term (نا), this does not significantly affect the chain reliability, as direct terms are acceptable even from known mudallisun

Topics: Suppressing anger and its reward
Divine rewards for moral restraint
Incident of controlling rage

hadiths.english_translation: A thief was executed during the time of the Messenger of Allah ﷺ for the price of a shield, and the price of a shield was a dinar.

narrators.full_name: Yahya ibn Khalaf al-Hamdani (Abu Salamah)

narrators.name: Ibn Daud
narrators.full_name: Ubayd Allah ibn Daud or similar (murabat - mixing of transmitters)

narrators.alternative_names: al-Hasan ibn Salih, Abu Ali al-Thawri

chainIssues: Ibn Daud is majhul (completely unknown) - a critical weak point in the chain
This chain is mawquf (stopping at the companion Ayman), not marfu' (going to the Prophet ﷺ)
Multiple عَنِ and عَنْ transmissions throughout the chain
al-Hakam ibn Aban is Saduq Yukhtī (prone to errors), which affects reliability
The chain has a weak transmitter (majhul) which fundamentally affects its authenticity

potential_issues.issue: Ibn Daud (narrator position 2) is majhul (completely unknown narrator)
potential_issues.impact: This is a critical issue as majhul narrators make the hadith weak (Daif). We have no information about the reliability, integrity, or accuracy of this narrator

potential_issues.issue: The hadith is mawquf (stops at Ayman, a companion) not marfu' (reaching the Prophet ﷺ)
potential_issues.impact: The hadith is attributed to a companion only, not directly to the Prophet ﷺ. While the companion's account is valuable, it is less authoritative than a marfu' hadith

potential_issues.issue: al-Hakam ibn Aban is graded as Saduq Yukhtī (prone to errors)
potential_issues.impact: While not completely unreliable, al-Hakam's tendency to make errors in narration is a concern that affects the overall reliability of this chain

potential_issues.issue: The presence of multiple عَنِ/عَنْ transmissions without explicit hearing terminology
potential_issues.impact: Creates ambiguity about whether direct hearing occurred, especially with the weak narrators in the chain

Topics: Punishment for theft in Islamic law
Minimum value of stolen goods for cutting hand
Economic stipulations for legal penalties

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by the uncle of Rashid ibn Sa'd: The Messenger of Allah ﷺ said: 'If there remained from the total of existence only a single day, Allah would extend that (day).' This is strange, not known in the Levant.

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Shayban (the grandfather of Abu Hubaira): I entered the mosque and sat near the chamber of the Prophet ﷺ. The Prophet ﷺ heard me clearing my throat and said: 'Is that Abu Yahya?' I said: 'Yes.' He said: 'Come here to breakfast.' I said: 'I wish to fast.' He said: 'And I wish to fast, but our muezzin has some defect in his eye, and he has called the Adhan before the dawn has broken.' The judge said: 'I think he said...' and repeated 'And I wish to fast.'

narrators.name: Abu al-Sha'tha

potential_issues.impact: Both early weak points in the chain reduce overall reliability

potential_issues.issue: The chain is mawquf (attributed to the companion Shayban), not directly to the Prophet ﷺ

hadiths.english_translation: That the Messenger of Allah ﷺ said: 'Verily in my nation there is a man who shall enter Paradise by his intercession more than the Banu Tamim.'

chainIssues: Al-Hasan ibn Rustam is majhul (completely unknown) - critical weak point

potential_issues.issue: Al-Hasan ibn Rustam is majhul (completely unknown narrator)

potential_issues.issue: Qatadah is a classified mudallis (category 3) and uses عَنْ (indirect transmission term)
potential_issues.impact: Qatadah is known to practice tadlis and when using عَنْ with an unknown narrator (al-Hasan ibn Rustam), this becomes problematic. Direct transmission terms (حدثنا/سمعت) should be expected from mudallisun for reliability

potential_issues.issue: The matn uses أن (inna) which indicates indirect attribution

potential_issues.issue: Al-Hasan ibn Rustam appears nowhere in standard hadith biographical works

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Jiddar: We fought with the Messenger of Allah ﷺ and met our enemy alongside the Messenger of Allah ﷺ. He stood and praised Allah and thanked Him, then said: 'O people, verily you have dawned upon you from Allah the Mighty and Majestic blessings of green, yellow, and red, and in the homes what they contain. When you meet your enemy, advance, advance! For verily there is no one among you who fights in the way of Allah except that two of the Houri come forth to him. If he fights they hide from him. If he is martyred, the first drop of blood that falls from his body, Allah will expiate by it every sin of his, then they come and sit by his head, and wipe from his face, and say to him: Welcome, it is time for you. And he says: Welcome, it is time for you.'

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Matiir: You told me O father that you met Dhu al-Yadayn at Dhu Khashab, and he informed you that the Messenger of Allah ﷺ prayed with them one of the two evening prayers which was the Asr prayer, then he performed the taslim. Some people hastily left saying: 'Has the prayer been shortened? Has the prayer been shortened?' The Messenger of Allah ﷺ stood and Dhu al-Yadayn caught up with him and said: 'O Messenger of Allah, has the prayer been shortened or did you forget?' He said: 'The prayer has not been shortened nor did I forget.' Then he turned to Abu Bakr and Umar and said: 'What does Dhu al-Yadayn say?' They said: 'He is right, O Messenger of Allah.' So the Messenger of Allah ﷺ returned and the people returned, and he prayed two more rak'ahs, then performed the taslim, then performed two prostrations of forgetfulness.

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Dhu al-Zawaid: The Messenger of Allah ﷺ said in the year of the Farewell Pilgrimage, he commanded the people and prohibited them, then said: 'Did I convey?' They said: 'Yes O Allah,' twice, he said: 'O Allah bear witness, O Allah bear witness.' Then he said: 'Take from the gift what was a gift, so if Quraysh disputed between them the kingdom, and the gift became or was a ransom against your religion, then leave it.'

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Dhu Mikhmar: The Messenger of Allah ﷺ said: 'You will make a secure truce with the Romans until you fight together against an enemy and you will be victorious and you will descend in a meadow of two hills.'

narrators.name: Al-Hawti
narrators.full_name: Abd al-Rahman ibn Malik al-Mudlaji (called al-Hawti)

narrators.name: Baqiyyah ibn al-Walid
narrators.full_name: Ismail ibn Raja' ibn Rabi'ah al-Zubaydi (called Baqiyyah ibn al-Walid)

narrators.name: Safwan ibn Amr
narrators.full_name: Ziyad ibn Fayrudh al-Baraa' (called Safwan ibn Amr)

narrators.name: Ibn Sa'd
narrators.full_name: Bahlul ibn Muwarraq al-Shami (called Ibn Sa'd incorrectly)

potential_issues.issue: Baqiyyah ibn al-Walid is known for mixing narrations from different sources without clear distinction
potential_issues.impact: While Saduq in grade, his mixing of narrations can affect the reliability and purity of transmission from his source

potential_issues.issue: The transmission is relatively straightforward with direct terms, but the subject matter (future events) requires careful scrutiny

Topics: Treaty with the Romans (Byzantine)
Prophecy about unified fighting against common enemy
Eschatological prediction about Romans and Muslims
Description of a place called meadow of two hills

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Jubair ibn Nufayr: Jubair ibn Nufayr said to me: Come with us to Dhu Mikhmar who was a companion of the Prophet ﷺ. I went with him and Jubair asked him about the truce. He said: I heard the Messenger of Allah ﷺ saying: 'You will make a secure truce with the Romans, then you and they fight against an enemy together, you will be victorious and you will gain spoils and will be safe, then you will return until you descend in a meadow of two hills. Then a man from the Christians will raise the cross and will say: The cross has conquered. Then a man from the Muslims will become angry and rise up to him and strike it. At that time the Romans will break the truce and gather for battle.'

chainIssues: The chain has multiple عَنْ and عَنِ transmissions which can introduce ambiguity about direct hearing
However, most narrators are graded as Thiqah or Saduq which are generally reliable
The matn contains details about the breaking of the truce when the cross is raised and struck down
The chain demonstrates dialogue and narrative elements that suggest a mawquf beginning (narrative by Jubair about visiting Dhu Mikhmar)

potential_issues.issue: The chain contains multiple عَنْ/عَنِ transmissions without explicit hearing terminology in several places
potential_issues.impact: While the narrators are generally reliable, the use of عَنْ can introduce ambiguity about direct hearing, particularly with prophetic traditions

potential_issues.issue: The matn contains narrative elements describing Jubair's visit to Dhu Mikhmar and questioning him
potential_issues.impact: The hadith appears to have a narrative framework (mawquf style) embedded within what is presented as marfu'

potential_issues.issue: The subject matter concerns prophetic predictions about future events with the Romans
potential_issues.impact: Such predictions warrant careful examination as they may be subject to interpretation and variation across different narrations

Topics: Peace treaty between Muslims and Romans
Joint military campaign against common enemy
Description of events at meadow of two hills
Raising of the cross by Christians
Muslim reaction to the cross
Breaking of the Roman truce
Prophecy about Roman betrayal
Eschatological battle scenario

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Dhu Mikhmar ibn Akhii al-Najashi: That the Messenger of Allah ﷺ said: 'You will make a secure truce with the Romans for ten years, during which they will keep their covenant for two years and breach it in the third, or keep it for four years and breach it in the fifth. A force from you will camp in their city and you will fight together against an enemy behind you and behind them. You will kill that enemy and Allah will open for you. You will return with reward and spoils and descend in a meadow of two hills. Then one of you will say: Allah the Mighty and Majestic has conquered. And one of them will say: The cross has conquered. They will dispute about it for a while. Then the Muslims will become angry and from them the cross is not far. A man from the Muslims will rise to their cross and strike it. They will strike his neck and kill him. Then that band of Muslims will rise to their weapons and the Romans will rise to their weapons and they will kill that band of Muslims and they will be martyred. They will come to their king and say: We have sufficed you from the heat of war and their might. So what do you await? He will gather for you the size of a pregnancy of a woman and then comes to you under eighty banners, under each banner twelve thousand.'

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Dhu Mikhmar ibn Akhi al-Najashi: The Messenger of Allah ﷺ said: 'You and the Romans will make a secure truce for ten years, then they will breach it in the third or fifth year. A force from you will camp in their city then you will fight together against an enemy from behind them. They will return safe and gaining spoils until you descend in a meadow of two hills. Then one of them will say: The cross has conquered, and one of you will say: Allah the Mighty and Majestic has conquered. They will exchange these words and the cross is not far from them. Then one of you will rise to the cross and break it. They will rise to him and kill him. Then you will rise to your weapons and they will rise to their weapons. Allah will defeat that band of Muslims so none of them escapes except those carrying the mark. They will return to their king and say: We have sufficed you from the war of the Arabs and their might. What do you await? They will gather for you the size of a nine-month pregnancy and come to you under eighty banners, under each banner twelve thousand. Then the Messenger of Allah ﷺ said: That is the great slaughter.'

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Dhu Mikhmar: We were on a journey with the Messenger of Allah ﷺ. The Prophet ﷺ hastened the journey and the people fell behind him. Someone said: O Messenger of Allah, the people have fallen behind you. He sat down until the people caught up with him. The Prophet ﷺ or one of them said: Would you like a nap? This was acceptable to them. They said: Yes, may Allah make us your ransom. He descended and they descended. The Prophet ﷺ said: Who will guard us tonight? Dhu Mikhmar said: I will, O Messenger of Allah, may Allah make me your ransom. He gave me his she-camel and said: Here, do not be lazy. I took the she-camel's halter and moved away a little. I was guarding while they grazed. Sleep overtook me and I did not wake until I felt the sun's heat on my face. I looked right and left and found the two camels nearby. I went to them and took their halters and came to the people who were sleeping. I woke the nearest one and asked: Did you pray? He said: No. Some of them woke the others until the Prophet ﷺ woke. He said: Bilal, is there water in the waterskin? He said: Yes, may Allah make me your ransom. He performed ablution without wiping off the dust, stood and prayed two rak'ahs without haste, then ordered Bilal to call the Adhan. He called the Iqamah and prayed with them without haste. Someone asked: O Messenger of Allah, have we neglected? He said: Allah took our souls and then returned them to us, and we have prayed.

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Dhu al-Ghurrah: I asked the Messenger of Allah ﷺ and said: We go out in the desert land and prayer comes upon us while we are near water. Do we pray in the places where camels rest? He said: No. I said: Do we perform ablution from their meat? He said: Yes. I said: Do we pray in the places where sheep rest? He said: Yes. I said: Do we perform ablution from their meat? He said: No.
